comments.commentBody: Exactly right, Scott.  We're arguing about the wrong things.  There's enough on this planet for everyone, but not by the way we're wasting it.

The world ought to be thinking about the depletion of resources, extiction of species, and environmental damage that cannot be reversed. The drive for the accumulation of great wealth on an individual level is impoverishing humanity and the planet in a macro sense. People need to work in constructive endeavors, be free of the nonsensical policies that take money out of circulation, and wisely use a decent living wage for their betterment, that is mindful of the responsibilities each of us bear. The ability to produce vast supplies of products through robotics may create a temporary increase in demand due to a more competitive price, but the lag in the supply of customers with enough money, will eventually take a deflationary toll.

Stand alone capitalism doesn't provide the answers to the questions we should be, but aren't even asking.

replies.commentBody:
During Keynes' life, the low income production of consumer goods took place in West countries: Southern cotton factor books show payments of a penny a pound for a decade or longer for picking cotton. Women worked incredible hours in New England factories for little pay. Child labor was woven into America's fabric, from PA mines to New England mills to Southern farms. In the 1930s, hoers received 75 cents a day.

A main difference was not the export of jobs or low wages, but that goods were cheaper relative to income. That difference in value has found itself exported upward to the global top tier whose wealth has expanded exponentially in away that wages have not. The rise in costs and prices has lead to a raise in wealth!

But cheap labor abounded then and now; its relocation has less to do with recovery than its exploitation for greater wealth.

American wages once drove demand. But look carefully, and one finds a broad global middle class that includes the Chinese, India, Brazil, Europe, and parts of West and Southern Africa. The American middle class fits into this cohort of consumers. No longer the leaders because of national policies, not exported wages.

Relatively speaking Brasil's and China's middle wages are not higher than the US, but their growth is enhanced even as lower wages are found in their countries and among their neighbors.

Countries with a growing middle class protect that middle class. There US policy falls short.

@walterrhett: I was reared in one of those New England factory towns in the 1930s. There were then three textile mills, two shoe factories, one large cotton print works, and an electrical goods factory. They were the mainstay of the local economy and provided most of our employment when they ran all out, i.e. more than one shift. During the worst of the Depression they sat idle or ran part time. They began to pick up in employment when the Keynesian ideas were being practiced under FDR in the early 1930s. A cut back in that program led to a slump in 1937. Things picked up again with the spending related to WWII. Relative prosperity continued post war, even as the textile and shoe factories closed down, unable to compete with imports. The electrical goods factory picked up the slack. Eventually that too was sold out and production moved overseas.

That small city today is half the size that it was, with empty real estate everywhere and a chronic unemployment problem that shows no sign of improvement. Increased spending on shoes, cloth or electrical goods will not help. Too late!

Those memories and my later memories of studying Keynes' writings, under the tutelage of professors of his own and a slightly later generation are what
cause me to believe that the Theory needs a contemporary revision to take into consideration a global economy that includes an industrialized low wage China, with Indonesia, Bangladesh and Vietnam, etc. rapidly entering the scene.

Keynes ideas are still valid, but need expansion to cope with new challenges to employment in Western nations -- cheap labor imports and a computer driven second industrial revolution.

I think as long as we stay in the realm of capitalism that is, any hiring happens by mutual agreement (there are some distorting minimum wage laws but there is no legal obligation to hire or apply for a job so these laws do not really "help poor"), there is no such things as more or less fair tax. Any change in tax system will be compensated by negotiation of employee and employer under the condition of un-changed ratio of negotiating powers of the sides as well as by lobbying. If anything, any complication favors the stronger (i.e. the richer) side as they will probably adapt more rapidly and precisely, using professional help they can more readily afford.

Therefore I believe the "fairest" or rather "best" tax system is the cheapest, simplest and least intrusive one. Taxing land and maybe some other real property that already has to be registered by law would probably be the simplest and would not require expensive and constitutionally and morally questionable IRS. Taxing imports and exports falls into the same category but has other consequences if the rates are significant. Flat tax is also one of the simplest and at that the best although many people think it's the most unfair one -- but see above about fairness.

To summarize, the best tax is simple and low. Of course, to lower e.g. Federal taxes, we need to get the functions of Federal government back to their Constitutional limits.
